element_texts.text:
Daily pocket remembrancer for 1862.
New York: For the trade.

Geo. M. Templeton
Co. D. 149th Regt. P.V.
From Canonsburg Penn.

TUESDAY, January 7th, 1862
Subject of Dr (unclear) sermon
Hebrew 15 & 16 Proposed to give some
reasons why we should not forget
to do good.  1st Because by doing
so we assimilize ourselves to God
2nd Because we have constantly before God
the example of our blessed Lord,
3rd Because it promotes our own happiness
4th Because your skin is (unclear)
this duty in the Bible.
Finally, Because by such sacrifices
we best express our gratification to
God & our indebtness to him for
his kindness & goodness to us.
Sermon was 44 min in length
The text in the evening was in II
Peter 3 & 18.  As this was the
second sermon in the text, I could
not catch up the divisions.
The three leading evidences of growth

WEDNESDAY, January 22D, 1862
Exchange Bank      Pitt

                                        $14.00

Citizens Bank Pitt                  7.00
Mer & Man. Bank Pitt         12.00


THURSDAY 23

SATURDAY 13

FRIDAY, JANUARY 31ST, 1802

Sharp
Pictures
Pin & chain

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1


SUNDAY 2

TUESDAY, JANUARY 28TH, 1862
Pittsburg return
Bonnet, skilet, lamp

WEDNESDAY 29
THURSDAY 30

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 6TH 1862.
Philadelphia.
Fell down stairs - weight
struck her on back of head -
insensible for some time
Havenford St near 44 st
Look at flats & see whether they
are broad or narrow will
ask if the matron knows
whether she needs anything.
Drig
L Myers 101 State St
B Waterwille army
SATURDAY 8
Union 17 members 5 Senior
Hamilton 36
Rochester 5 Truck 5 Soph 9w 3 hen
Middlebury 2 sen. 1 fr. 2 soph 6 fresh
Rutgers 5 em 4 dr 17m all
Waterwill 20. 13 in war

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8D, 1862
New York
Internation? Hotel cor of Franklyn
St & Broadway
Trinity Church Broadway
Opposite Wall St
TUESDAY 4
1Jefferson, 2 Williams
3. Time & place of meeting.
4 Catalogue
5 Other publishing
6 Unanimous vote
7 Corresponding Secretary
WEDNESDAY 5
Recommendation
1  Corresponding Secretary
2  Songs

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12TH, 1862
Hamilton College
Envelops

THURSDAY 13



FRIDAY 14

SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9TH, 1862
Albany
Unanimous vote
Corresponding Secretary.
Smart
June 6 kel waggoner 3.50

MONDAY 10


TUESDAY 11

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1862
Niagra Falls
Flowers

SUNDAY 16



MONDAY 17

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 5TH, 1862
Fare from Cannonburg                                                   15 Pittsburg

                                                                                      $1.00

"                    "        Pittsburg to N.Y                               $12.50
Dinner in Harrisburg                                                             .50
Supper in Philadelphia                                                       1.50
"                    "        New York                                              .35
Fare & birth to Albany                                                        1.50
THURSDAY 6
Breakfast in Albany                                                               .75
Fare to (unclear)                                                                   .35
Fare to Niagra Falls                                                            5.78
"                      "  Buffalo                                                       .60
"                      "  Pittsburg                                                 4.25
Dinner in Niagra City                                                            .50
Supper "                                                                              .38]
FRIDAY 7
Breakfast in Cleveland                                                         .25
Fare for Buff to Cleveland                                                 5.00
"                        "  Pitt to Canonsburg                               1.00

FRIDAY, MARCH 14TH, 1862


                                                        S E N T


Friday Nov 19th                                     Margaretta & Aunt Maria

         Nov  17th                                    Mother & A A Coleman
                 20                                       Sarah Ann.
                 29th                                    Mary

Dec 2nd                                                Mother

      1st                                                 Jim Le Black.
      2nd                                                D.R Waggoner
      3rd                                                 Ed. R. Geary
     15th                                                Mother & Father on the 12th
     20                                                   Lug Calver
     26th                                                Mother
     27th                                                Margaretta
     31st                                                Sarah Ann Jim Black

Jan 18th      1853                                 Eliza Jane & Mother
2nd                                                      Hamilton College

     14th                                               Father
     15th                                               Mother
     17th                                               Culver
     18                                                  Musser

MONDAY, MARCH 17TH 1862
Jan 21st      Mame & Margaretta (unclear)

     22nd     Ypms Young
     23        Father
     26        Mother
     27        Mother (likeness)
     28        A.S Thompson & Samuel
     29        Jim Wilson
     30        Jim Black


Feb 2nd     Father

      4         Sarah Anne
      6         Dispatch
      7         Geo (unclear) Templeton 


WEDNESDAY 19

[SUNDAY. April 13th, 1862]
RECEIVED
Nov 14/62    Waggoner  x

 "    17th       Home x & Jim Wilson  x
 "    18th       Jim Black  x
 "    19th       Sarah Ann  x
 "     20 "       Mr. Reed
 "     22 "      Mame x & Add Coleman
                                                               [MONDAY 14]
"     28th      Alex S. Thompon  x

Dec 13th      Mother  x

 "    18th      Margaretta  x
 "    19 "       Father.   x
 "     27 "      Mary. x
 "    28 "       Mrs. S. Young .  x
                                                                [TUESDAY 15]
 "     "   "      Father x  & Waggoner
 "    30 "      Geo. M. Reed x
 "    31 "      Culver x  & Jim Black  x

Jan 1st 1853 Mother  x

"    8"     "    Wm S. Young x
"   10     "     Elviza June x
"   12    "     Sarah Ann & Jim Black
"   14    "     Margaretta  x

[WEDNESDAY,  April 16th, 1862]

Jan 15    Mother x

"    18    Sarah Ann, Templeton & [?Mary?]
"    23    Father & Mother  x
"   24     Wm S Young & Musser
"   28     Father & Samuel  x

Feb 3rd  Sarah Ann

"  5th     Mother                                              [ THURSDAY 17]

"   8th     Geo M. Reed.


                                                                         [ FRIDAY 18]

[FRIDAY, APRIL 25TH, 1862]

Jan 1st
This was a great day in this city. In the forenoon all the distinguished military men in the city called in a body on Sec. Stanton. at the head of the column was Gen Halleck.   I recognised Gen. H. Gen Heintzlman, Gen Cadwalader, Gen Mc Dowell, Garfield etc                   [SATURDAY 26]
In the afternoon I went to the President's reception. Had the pleasure of shaking hands with "Honest Abe." He seemed in good spirits & looked well. Went to the Soldier's Free Library & along with about 2000 soldiers received some apples & cakes sent by the ladies of Mass                 [SUNDAY 27]
Jan 2nd
Nothing of interest happened today 
Jan 3rd
Ditto
Jan 4th
Attended Dr, Gurly's Church in the morning, as I went on guard at (1?)

[THURSDAY, May 1st, 1862]
arrests.  The appropriation bill was up in the House.  Met Jeff Patton on his way to visit the Potomac army   He said Joh Boon & one of Arnolds were along with him.  Harry's father came today Jan 9..

 [ FRIDAY, May 2]

Harry received a telegrapic [sic]  dispatch went to congress to find him.  Some member of the House from Mo made a speech to which Bingham replyed in a very able & cuting one saw the affair of the policeman & the soldier in reference to which there was a motion introduced in the House.
[SATURDAY 8]
Jan 10
Rained almost all day.
Jan 11
Attended Dr Gurly's.  Some stranger [crossed out: preached]   Dr. Orley of Ct one of the See of the Colonization Society

Pres met contrabands at cor of 16 & H Sts & welcomed them

                                                                                                [MONDAY, April 28th, 1862]

o'clock I could not stay until the close of the exercises.  Went to 14 St church in the evening.
Jan 5th
Commenced drilling by number
Jan 6th                                                                                       [TUESDAY 29]
Harry went to the Depot to meet his father whom he was expecting to join him on visit.  Did not come.
Jan 7th
Went to Congress:  Field of N.J made a long speech on the Habeas Corpus question                                          [WEDNESDAY 30]
In the House the "Bankrupt bill was discussed at length. 
{crossed out:  Harry's father is not coming until next week.]
Jan 8
Went to Congress.  Saulsbury of Del made a dissession speech on illegal

[ SUNDAY, MAY 4TH, 1862]

preached from Psalm 68 & 31 not much sermon about it
Jan 12
Went to Congress.  Bingham used up the Secesh again on the confiscation act.  recd letters from Jim Black & S.A.

                                                                                                                                                                                   [MONDAY 5]

Jan 13.
Went to Congress today again   Most of the time was Spent in eulogics on Senator Pierce of Md.
Jan 14                                                                                                                                                    [crossed out:  TUESDAY 6]
Went to Congress again  Bing of [?] & Wright of Pa made strong speech in reply to a peace speech of Valandingham.
Jan 15
On guard from 1 PM until 5  Corp Stewart & men went to [?Frinsly?] Church to attend a

[MONDAY, MAY 19TH, 1862]

Left Rochester 7.35 AM arriving in Niagria [sic] Falls 10.25 AM  Went down & up stairway - to Goat Island - cave of the Winds - Tower - Suspension Bridge - Canada side of the Falls &c.  Left Niagria 6:30 PM arriving Buff 7.30 which left 10.40 PM

                             [ TUESDAY 20]

Arrived in Cleaveland [sic] at 5.30 AM  Left Cleaveland 9.30 AM arriving in Pittsburg 3.30 AM

                              [WEDNESDAY 21]

Left Pittsburg 5.30 AM getting home at 10.30 AM

[FRIDAY, MAY 16TH, 1862]

Left Utica for Clinton 7½  arriving in Clinton at 9½ AM

                                                                                            [SATURDAY, 17]

Left Clinton 8½ AM arriving in Utica 10 AM
Left Utica 11 AM arriving, by way of Auburn, in Rochester at 5.25 PM

                                                                                           [SUNDAY 18]

Went to Babtist church at 10 ½ 

  "     "    St Peter's Presbyterian Church at 2 PM.  Rev Mr Coit pastor

[SUNDAY, MAY 25TH, 1862]

[?Funeral?]:  they went out to the soldiers Home.
Jan 16
{note in margin:]  See in packet
very cold today
Jan 17
Still cold.  Reading"Casey Tactics"

                                                           [MONDAY 16]  

Jan 18
Read 12 chapters of Mathew while on guard from 1 AM until 5 AM.  Attended Dr. Gurly's.  Text Exodus 19 & 10 & 11.  The sacratment was observed there.  Dr. Baird of NY & some other man assisted    [TUESDAY 27]      
Lieut Slagle came back this morning bringing a letter from S. A. & Templeton.
Jan 19
went to a methodist Missionary meeting
Nothing of interest today
Jan 20
[?] [?wet weather?]

[SATURDAY, MAY 31ST, 1862]
[crossed out: SUNDAY, JUNE 1]    Oct 29-62
While eating dinner orders came to pack knapsacks and march fully armed and equiped for Georgetown.  In ½ an hour we were on the road, at the double quick.
Arriving in Georgetown [MONDAY 2] Capt Stratton of Comp H took command of us and we received 160 stragglers and deserters in charge to be delivered to the Provost Marshal at Harpers Ferry.  Marched to the Washington Depot got our suppers at the Retreat - go in freight cars at 10 PM and started at 12 PM

[WEDNESDAY, MAY 25TH, 1862]
Jan 21
Very muddy
Jan 22
Received our pay up to the 1 & 5 of Nov.  I need $.17.33c pay for 1 month & 10 days
[THURSDAY 29]
Jan 23
Subscribed for "The Chronicle"  Went Congress.  Spoke to Sen. Lane of Kansas.  He invited me to call and see him.
Jan 24
Received the first no of the Chronical.  Charlie & [?] Marks {crossed out: got] were put in the "central Guard House" for not having a date on their pass..
Jan 25
attended Dr. Gurly's church - Dr. Baird of N.Y. preached a missionary sermon.

[FRIDAY, JUNE 6TH, 1862]
by Gen McClellans headquarters, which is a Sibley tent.   We delivered our prisoners over to a guard of the 8th Regulars, who are camped there.  The water here is excelent the best I have had since I left home.               [SATURDAY 7]

 The country between the Relay House and Harper's Ferry is pretty rough, with the exception of some near the "Monacacy" principaly on the western side, where there are some good farms.
  They were busy building the bridge over the Monacacy which had been destroyed by the rebels a short time before.        [SUNDAY 8]
  After delivering up our charge we marched back a short distance to Berlin where we awaited the cars.  Capt Glenn, who was 2nd in command, bought us 2 biscuit apiece  Got on a passenger train about

[TUESDAY, JUNE 3D, 1862]
Got to the Relay House about 7 AM.  The country between Washington and this place is very rough and very little [?cultiv?] leaving there, we arrived at the Maryland end of the Harpers Ferry bridge about 9 [?] as the tressle work of the bridge had been accidentally burnt the day before, we could not pass over.        [WEDNESDAY 4]

  After getting out of the cars we found that the Provost Marshals office was back about 6 miles on the way we came.  Marched back about 5 miles and as we could not find the place we camped out for the night without anything to eat.    [THURSDAY 5]

I should have said that we started with one day's rations, and had no chance to buy any.  It was very cold.   We we [sic] on the march by day break and after marching about a mile we found the place we were seeking.  It was situated in a wood, close

[MONDAY, JUNE 9TH, 1862]
4 P.M. arriving at the Relay House about 7 we were transfered to freight cars and arrived in Washington about 11 PM and at camp at 1 AM of Saturday.   The Penn Reserves crossed the river a few hours before we went up or I would have had a chance of seeing Co D 10 Regt.  Saw Frank Richey in charge of an ambulance         [TUESDAY 10]
train.  While at Berlin saw Gen Burnside.  he was riding around with a check shirt on.  he looked like a very practical Gen
[WEDNESDAY  11]

[SATURDAY, AUGUST 23D, 1862]  
Loafed
[SUNDAY 24]
Went to hear Mr Brown at 10 ½ AM, and Read on 7th St at 7 ½ PM
[MONDAY 25]
Loafed

[WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20TH, 1862.  THURSDAY 21  FRIDAY 22]
Enlisted in Capt Glenn's comp and was mustered into service about 11 PM

[FRIDAY, AUGUST 29TH, 1862]  
Arrived in Harrisburgh at 5.20 AM went into Camp Curtin got our breakfast about 10 AM    Went into Col Roy Stone's 149 Penn Vol Reg as Company D.
[SATURDAY 30]
Did not sleep much last night being the first night in camp.  marched out to town in the forenoon and received our arms and equipments - got back about 2 PM & while eating dinner got orders to get our uniforms and march at 5 PM.  It kept us pretty busy.  After getting into freight cars got very sick & by the kindness of Glen & Slagle got a seat in the officer's car.                          [SUNDAY 31]
Arrived in Baltimore about 6 o'clock, and although very sick I carried my knapsack and gun through the city.  The regiment got a good breakfast at the "Soldier's Rest" and left for Washington in the same kind of cars, about 10 AM arriving about 5 PM  The reg got their dinner at the "Soldiiers Retreat".  Marched down Penn. Aven. and out of town & camped without supper or tents on the wet ground                   [(5*)]

[TUESDAY, AUGUST 26TH, 1862]  
Loafed
[WEDNESDAY 27]
Got our [?county?] bounty of $ .10 cash and a $.50 bond and had orders to march at 8.20 PM, which was countermanded at 6 PM
[THURSDAY 28]
Got our U.S bounty of $27 and left Pittsburgh at 8.20 P.M. arrived in Harrisburgh at 5.30 AM of Friday

[THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH, 1862]
Worse again.  As most of the company have gon on Provost duty in the city Lieut Slagle took me into his tent.
[FRIDAY 5]
Worse.  Dr Stratton has not been to see me since.  Some of the soldiers had a Methodist camp meeting in the rear of my tent last night:  They made a great noise, carrying on like the "Darkies" do at home
[SATURDAY 6]
Worse.  Dr. S. cannot be found.  Lieut Slagle sent to Cliffburne Hospital for a doctor.  he said he would come after dinner sent after dinner, said he would be over in a few minutes.  Waited until about 5 o'clock when Dr Stratton came around, and they sent me in an ambulance to Cliffburne Hospital

[MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 1ST, 1862]
Moved early in the morning further out, and laid down on the grass until the detachments from the companies had pitched the tents on Kalorama Heights, where we moved in the evening in the midst of a pouring rain.
[TUESDAY 2]
Still sick and lying in Camp which we call "camp STone".  after our Col:  Our Liut Col Dwight seems like a very nice man.
[WEDNESDAY 3]
A little better today.  Capt Stratton who is a doctor gave me some medicine.

[WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10TH, 1862.]
Got Saturday's Chronicle:  It seemed like home to read it.  Somewhat better.  Stoped [sic] taking medicine.
[THURSDAY 11]
Better but very weak:  lie in bed about 22 hours of the day.   This morning they ordered me with all those who were geting [sic] better out for muster to see if we were well enough for to go back to our regiments:  it came on rain while out.
[FRIDAY 12]
A good deal stronger.  Took a good wash in the creek, changed my under clothes for the first time since I left home: reason because I did not get a change from the government until now.  Got a letter from Father & Mother enclosing one from Waterloo N.Y.

[SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 7TH, 1862.]
Slept pretty well last night having an iron bedstead & a matress bed to lie on.  There is a testament under the head of every bed.  I believe there was some kind of preaching in camp.   I was too weak to go.   Dr. Colton came to see me & prescribed for me 
[MONDAY 8]
About the same.  We get bread (Toast if you want it). beafsteak, butter & milk for breakfast and supper.  Some kind of soup, bread & potatoes for dinner.   Lemonade sometimes if you want it.  Ice water at all times.
[TUESDAY 9]
A little better.  There is plenty of reading matter here. such as Harper's Monthly, Emerson Magazine &c &c.  I got a letter from Sara Ann on Saturday & one from father & mother on Sabbath: they were as good as a dose of medicine.

[TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16TH, 1862]
Pretty tired after yesterday's walk - A. S. Thompson came to see me; he has been in the city some time and is going back to college.  went over to camp with him but Stewart & Nicholls were out on duty.  Wrote home
[WEDNESDAY 17]
Nothing new today, looking to be discharged from the hospital at any time.  Wrote to Sarah Ann.
[THURSDAY 18]
Nothing of interest took place today.   Wrote to mother today

[SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13TH, 1862.
Getting pretty strong.   About 9 PM heard the long roll beat over in our camp and a great hubbub following:  thought they were preparing to march.  Found out that the Suttler had passed counterfeit money which he would not redeem.  The boys were tearing his tent down.
[SUNDAY 14]
Spent a very pleasant Sabbath.  Got 2 more books out of the Library (McIlwain Evidences of Christ & Life of the Hildane brothers)   In the afternoon attended the sermon by the Chaplain of the Hospt. about 75 present
[MONDAY 15]
Went to the city - Saw the monument - Went through the Treasury, War & Paymaster's Departments.  Saw Robertson had a pleasant talk with him.  Went to the Smithsonian Institute; it is very fine - went to the Capitol, being a hospital could not get in.  Saw the 112th NY  Saw the White House - Statue of Washington [?]   Saw Gen Halleck walking along the street, he met the Russian Minister and had a chat with him, seeming in a very good humor, having just heard from McClellan at Hag ton

[MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 22D, 1862.]
Got my discharg [sic] this morning about 9 o'clock, and came over and reported for duty to Capt Glenn - he promised to not put me on very hard duty for a while.
[TUESDAY 23]
Did not do very much.
[WEDNESDAY 24]
The company came back from the Hospitals

[FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19TH, 1862]
Corp. Johnston brought over a letter from Mary and a PM Chronicle: Lieut S. told him to send me over to sign the pay rolls for 13 doll adv.  went over & marched around for 2 hours & then did not get it.  Heard that could get [?bucktails?] in Georgetown got a pass & 2 dollars from Lieut S to get some, not very good ones got 14 for $1
[SATURDAY 20]
Still better - gave in my name for a discharge.
[SUNDAY 21]
About 200 or 300 convalescents were mustered for discharge - I went up but by some mistake my name was not on the roll - asked the Dr about it he promised to give me one tomorrow

[SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 28TH, 1862.]
The company were detailed to go to the hospitals in the city.  Went with 3 men to Epiphany Hospital.  Attended church at NY Ave Pres Church where Mrs. Lincoln attends - saw her and her two boys.  Found Dav. Cunningham in the hospital.  attended church in the evening 
[MONDAY 29]
As they did not need me I was ordered to report at Ascension Hospital - 3 men there - Drs very cross.
[TUESDAY 30]
Went back to camp after dinner being relieved by Comp F.  Visited the Patent office.  It has some of the finest things I have seen - the presents from the Japanese &c  There are hundreds of patents of the same machine.  It is now used as a hospital, there being 700 or 800 patients

[THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 25TH, 1862.]
Went on Batallion drill this morning for 3½  hours.  It was pretty hard for the first time
[FRIDAY 26]
Still drilling
[SATURDAY 27]
Ditto

[SATURDAY, OCTOBER 4TH, 1862.]
Guard was relieved at 8 o'clock.  Received a letter yesterday from Waggoner also.  went to town again and got some more bucktails from which I made something.
[SUNDAY  5]
Nothing but inspection of arms & dress parade - the most like Sabbath of any day yet.
[MONDAY 6]
The company were ordered to guard hospitals being a little behind time  they were divided into squads and thrown into other companies by order of John E Parsons Adjt. of the 149th Regiment of Pennsylvania volunteers

[WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 1ST, 1862]
Drilling
[THURSDAY 2]
Ditto
[FRIDAY 3]
Company on camp guard.  Lieut Slagle capt of guard.  Sergt Stewart Corps Cubbage Templeton & Jones.  got along very well for the first time.
Was not threatened with being reported as the others were.  Rec a letter from Rameburg & Co Georgetown went and got some very fine bucktails.

[FRIDAY, OCTOBER 10TH, 1862]
The company detailed for hospital guard  Sargent Stewart Corps Donnington Jones & myself - 24 men go to Finley Hosp first rate place  one of the men in the guard house broke out and having a large knife chased our guard (Johnston) Jones tied him for 24 hours when Nicholls & I took him and another man to the Soldier's Retreat
[SATURDAY 11]
Camp E detailed as permanent guard to Capitol Hill   Still on guard - The corps stand 4  hours on and 8 off.  raining slowly nearly all the time - they took 4 men from the hospital to be buried.  Jones & squad acting as escort, with arms reversed
[SUNDAY 12]
Were relieved about 12 M by Comp B   arrived in camp about 3 PM.  many rumors about being posted as permanent guards.  Wrote yesterday a letter enclosing $10.00 to Father - and one to Waggoner - mailed them this morning from Finley Hospital

[TUESDAY, OCTOBER 7th, 1862.]
Busy carrying grub over to our men at [?Carver?] Barracks
[WEDNESDAY 8]
The company came back today.
[THURSDAY 9]
Got letter from Father containing $2.00 and from Caldwell [A.K?] who is prof of Mathematics in Jefferson College now  Went downtown and got our $13 advance pay.  bought a camp knife for $[?] and laid in a supply of provisions.  & got put on extra duty for being behind the company

[THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16TH, 1862]
Off guard
[FRIDAY 17]
On guard - received a letter from Aunt Maria and two papers from Mary
[SATURDAY 18]
Got a pass, and took a holiday in town - Saw Gen Hunter.  Also Robertson.  Went through the "White House" the "East Room" is very fine.   Went to the National Observatory a finely arranged and managed affair.  Looked through the Spy Glass at the forts on the other side of the river   Saw the Hibernia steam fire Engine
[(6)]

[MONDAY, OCTOBER 13TH, 1862.]
A Sargt  3 corps & 20 men detailed from our company for Camp guard - as I am on extra duty I am one of the corporals.  Received a letter from Ed Gerary.  received one on Saturday from Jim Black.
[[TUESDAY 14]
Came off guard today - went over to Cliffburne in the afternoon.  rested all day.
WEDNESDAY 15]
On Guard again

[WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 22D, 1862]
On guard today - nothing new that I can think of  Nick & the rest fixed up the tent in good style
[THURSDAY 23]
Off Guard.  Rev Rankin came up to camp today: Sargt Stewart's wife came to the city with him
[FRIDAY 24]
On guard.  The 2nd DC Vol who were camped near here when we came here came back this evening and camped in the old place

[SUNDAY, OCTOBER 19TH, 1862.]
On guard - received a letter from Father yesterday.
[MONDAY 20]
This evening Adjt Gen Thomas visited our camp and presented state flags to ours and the 150th who were drawn up on our parade ground   After he was through Lieut Col proposed 3 cheers - given with a will
[TUESDAY 21]
All the companies except ours were detached and sent around to guard hospitals   we are to guard the camp   Comp "I" went to "Finley" - "A" to "carver" - "F" to "Armory Square" - "C" to "Judiciary Sq

[TUESDAY, OCTOBER 28TH, 1862]
On guard again
[WEDNESDAY 29]
While eating dinner received marching orders with knapsacks packed, fully armed and equiped. [sic]  In half an hour we were on the way to Georgetown on the double quick (i.e. 50 of us went
[THURSDAY 30]
For an account of this trip look on the page for June 1st

[SATURDAY, OCTOBER 25TH, 1862.]
As we do not expect to go down town for 5 or 6 days, we got orders to clean up the whole campground
Went down to Dr Robb's and got 2 cans of preserves sent by S.A. in Lieutenant Slagle's box.
[SUNDAY 26]
A great storm today, continuing with uninterupted [sic] rain until 10 AM of Monday.  Was on guard - had a very unpleasant time.  during the night the wind blew so violently that it drew up some of the pins of he tent leting [sic] it flap in on us
[MONDAY 27]
The afternoon turned out a pretty fine day.   Rev Rankin did not preach yesterday, as he intended, on account of the rain.  received a letter from Thos. H. Stewart yesterday saying that Weiss was drafted
Drew another blanket.

[MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3d, 1862.]
Moved our camp down to I St Cor of 15th quite a pretty place. had our tent fixed up as nice as it was before in an hour after we got our boards.
On guard 4 hours.  This day I am 21 years old I hope the next 21 may be better spent.
[TUESDAY 4]
William Campbell died today at 1 PM after a sickness of 5 or 6 days.
[WEDNESDAY 5]
On guard.  Received a letter from Ed Geary, written the day I was up the river.  I wish I could have seen him.  The Fathers of Gen Allison and Joe Baldwin came to see them bringing sundry boxes for the "boys"

[FRIDAY, OCTOBER 31ST, 1862]
Returned to Washington 12 PM
[SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 1]
Got to camp about 1 AM found a letter from home and also one from Margaretta and 2 papers from Mary.  Jacob Young had died in our absence.  The first from our company
[SUNDAY 2]
Attended church at the N.Y. Ave Pres church   The text was taken from 2 Cor. 4th & 18th  for the things that are seen are transformed but the things which are not seen are eternal.  There was a fire in town tonight.  Met Dr Douglass going to camp he was at N.Y. Ave church.

[SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 9TH, 1862]
The rest of the snow melted today.  28 of us went to N.Y. Ave Church.  Had a pretty thorough inspection in the afternoon by one of Gen Wadsworth's aids  he examined guns, knapsacks, canteens overcoats &c.  On guard today.
[MONDAY 10]
Receive a letter from Mary: wrote to another.
[TUESDAY 11]
A great many rumors of leaving

[THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 6TH, 1862.]
Nothing of interest happened today
[FRIDAY 7]
About 6 a.m it commenced snowing continuing all day and at evening there was 3 or 4 inches on the ground.  Harry went and got a stove with metal top and bottom, with extra pipe for 3.45. in a few minutes there were 6 or 7 in camp.  They heat a tent very well.
[SATURDAY 8]
A good deal of the snow melted off today.  
Received a long letter from Bob Musser.  Went down to market   Wrote to Mama.

[SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15TH, 1862.]
Went down to see Robertson:  met Gen McNary - Called to see William Templeton
[SUNDAY 16]
Pollock McNary, Bunnie McWilliams & Mr Wilson.  Pollock has been discharged from the 10th and got the appointment of adjt of the 123rd (Col clark)
[MONDAY 17]
Received letters from home and Jim Wilson

[WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 12TH, 1862.]
Ditto
[THURSDAY 13]
Saw Rev Turner Chaplain of 4th Penn Cav. being from canonsburg I hailed him and had a talk with him.
[?Jas?] McNary & L. McK Wilson called to see me.  Recd a letter from Waggoner  Saw Billy Temple
[FRIDAY 14]
Nothing of interest today.

[FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 21ST, 1862]
Very sore and as it has been raining and my tent leaks & I have no fit place to lie I went into the regimental hospital - about 8 PM put sweet oil on which stoped [sic] the pain.
[SATURDAY 22]
Recd letters from Mama & Add Colleman
[SUNDAY 23]
Still lying in the hospital

[TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 18TH, 1862.]
Nick & I went through the capitol today  The Senate Chamber is fine & the library  saw the $22,000 statue of Ben Franklin which had just arrived.
Received a letter from Jim Black.
[WEDNESDAY 19]
Went to the Dr this morning & received some powders.  Recd a letter from S. A.  Harrison recd his box - the butter tastes diffrent from that you buy here.  John E. Parsons came back today.
[THURSDAY 20]
Went to the Dr - he put Croton oil on my stomach - made it very sore before night - Recd a letter from Mr Reed with receipt for box.

[THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 27TH, 1862.]
Thanksgiving Day - the officers of the camp got up a fine dinner for the boys.  They had oysters, 6 turkies, a goose, some chickens, roast beef, boiled ham, sweet & Irish potatoes, apple sauce, ale & pies.
[FRIDAY 28]
They got boards today & all are busy fixing up their tents.  My young boy friend saw me today and finding out that I had been sick, said his mother would make me anything I wanted.  I beged [sic] off not wishing to trouble his mother.
[SATURDAY 29]

 About dinner time "my boy" and his mother came to the hospital to see me.  I was out at the time - she left a bottle of citrous & a glass of currant jelly & learning that I had not eaten any dinner, she went home & soon sent the little fellow back with a bowl of oysters, crackers & butter - Read a letter from A. S Thompson

[MONDAY, NOVEMBER 24TH, 1862.]
Pollock McNary, on his way to his regt, called to see me.  brought my watch and a letter from home containing my badge.
[TUESDAY 25]
Harrison went after my box
[WEDNESDAY 26]
Nothing new

[WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 3D, 1862.]
Nothing of interest
[THURSDAY 4]
Ditto.
[FRIDAY 5]
Snowed about 2 inches

[SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 30TH, 1862.]
"My boy" brought me a plate of rice pudding for supper - it was very good.
The disinterestedness of these people is something strange, and does more good than medicine.
John McWilliams &  John Chambers came to see me yesterday.  Johnny C. has been on a trip characteristic of the boy.
[MONDAY, DECEMBER 1]
I suppose Congress convened today; if it had been dry I would have asked the Dr for a pass to attend.  Saw a brigade march down [?] Avenue late last night, also today Jennings' brigade.  The 27 & 28 NJ & 24 Ct were 3 of the regiments.
[TUESDAY 2]
Nothing new today.  Nicholls & Harry went to Congress, but it had adjourned.

[TUESDAY, DECEMBER 9TH, 1862.]
Nothing of interest
[WEDNESDAY 10]
Went to Congress - The bill for the admission of Western Virginia was before the House.  Bingham of Ohio made an able speech in its favor, after which the vote was taken Ayes 95. Nays 56. - Met Jim Logan of Cannonsburg there
[THURSDAY 11]
Have not heard from home since the 24th of last month - Yesterday I stoped [sic] at the "Free Soldier's Library" and got some books.

[SATURDAY, DECEMBER 6TH, 1862.]
Very cold - freezing severely toward evening
[SUNDAY 7]
Had a very quiet Sabbath  Read 2 tracts:  one on "The Sabbath a day of rest" another on "Intemperance"  I also read the 3 Epistles of John and that of Jude
[MONDAY 8]
Read a number of tracts.  On the following subjects; "Ardent Spirits". "Drunkenness" "Dissapointed Hope", "To our Patriotic Volunteers"  The Steward tried to make me drink some of the ale ordered by the Dr.

[MONDAY, DECEMBER 15TH, 1862.]
Took a walk down town with Nicholls  Called at The Soldiers Free Library & got "Tom Brown of Oxford."  Received a letter on Saturday from Mother.
[TUESDAY 16]
Rained almost all night & until 8 AM.  Very windy all day.  Put out my washing in the morning.  Cooked all the meals today & rad a good deal.  Took Nick to the Free Library
[WEDNESDAY 17]
Went to Congress:  Saw Sumner, Wilson, Hamlin, Fessenden, Morrill.  Jim Lane Wilmot, Latham, Grimes, Sandsbury.  Powell of the senate.  Stephens, Lovejoy, Grow, Crittenden, Moorhead &c of the House   Took Harry to the Free Library

[(7*)]

[FRIDAY, DECEMBER 12TH, 1862.]
This was a great day for me - While at the Capitol I met Stephen Champ, he told me that their reg. was in the city - went to see them - Saw Feaser, Bingham, Weir, Sloan & Add Coleman, Murray McNary, Geo Murray all the rest.  Also Jim McFadden Co D [?10th?]
[SATURDAY 13]
Another great day - Went & told Robertson that the 14th Reg was in town; we got on the cars and went down.  I stayed until they left (4 PM).  On my way home met Dan Bullinger - Subscribed for the "Republican" for a month.
[SUNDAY 14]
Attended church at Dr Gurly's. - Text Romans I & 7 = In the evening I attended 6th St church, where B.F Morris preached a sermon on "Fast Young Men", from Titus 2 & 6 - On the way home, Sergt Major Sergt Easton, Corp Stewart & myself were taken to the Central Guard House, as our passes until 10 PM were not good after 9 PM.  By the help of Slagle got out at 12 P.M.

[SUNDAY, DECEMBER 21ST, 1862.]
Attended Dr Gurly's Church.  Text: Hebrews 13th & 16th.  Recd a letter from Mary   In the evening attended Dr Gurly's  Text II Peter 3 & 18th
[MONDAY 22] 
Went on guard today from 1 P.M. until 5 PM

[TUESDAY 23]

Went to Congress today, heard a very unpatriotic speech from a member from southern Illinois.  Bought a pair of boots for $3.75.  Met Mr Wilson on the street

[THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18TH, 1862.]
Read almost all day:  There were rumors yesterday & today of [?marching?] orders; but they were as usual [?only?] hoaxes.  Got a long letter from [?] Margaretten.
[FRIDAY 19]
Went to Congress.  heard a spirited [?passage?] between Morrill & Powell, in the Senate.  In the House some member from Md made a conservative speech, to which Judge Kelly of Phil replyed [sic] in a most able manner.  Recd a letter from Father   Saw Jim Chalfant on the Street.
[SATURDAY 20]
Nothing of interest happened today.

[SATURDAY, DECEMBER 27TH, 1862.]
Out on skirmish drill.
On guard from 9 PM.
Some lady presented the co with 3 turkies  The capt bought 2 more, all which were divided among the messes.
[SUNDAY 28]
Attended Dr Gurly's Text Acts 17 & 27 last clause.  In the evening he preached from the words. "Behold how great a matter a little fire kindleth"  A good sermon.
[MONDAY 29]
Got a pass until 5 PM.  Called on Mrs Turner  Called at Odd Felows [sic} Hall Hospital to see John Chambers.  He had been sent to Philadelphia.  Went to the Navy Yard  No admitance [sic] for enlisted men"  So I saw what I could from the out-side.  Stoped [sic] at Douglass Hospital to see Alex Musser: gone to his regiment.  Saw a great many wounded: one from Lawrence Co said his mother's friends [?Haneman?] by name lived in Washington Co. (To be continued)

[WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 24TH, 1862.]
Went out on skirmish drill for 2½ hours

[THURSDAY 25] 

Cepie Lustin "my boy" gave each man in the company a pie as a Christmas gift.  I made 16 apple dumplins [sic] for the four of us.  Had a very good dinner
[FRIDAY 26]
Got my watch fixed for .50 cts. something the matter with the winding.
On guard from 1 PM until 5 PM.  some persons brought things for a company dinner, but by mistake the [sic] went to the hospital  These were about 15 chickens, apples, oranges, pies, turnips &c.

[TUESDAY, DECEMBER 30TH, 1862.]
The soldier I was speaking of gave me a letter to [?] & send to [?Mr] W Davidson Laurence Co.  Called at the Patent Office hospital to see a Morrison of Clarks' reg it was not Sam Morrison of Washington Co.  Again dinner time my feet & ancles [sic] were so [?swole?] that I could not go on guard.  Ford's Theater [?burned?] down tonight went with the rest of the Co to the fire
[WEDNESDAY 31]
Not on duty.  There was a great fire last night Ford's Theater was burned down.  I along with the rest of Co went down.  After our [?return?] & roll call 11 fellows went to a negro concert by breaking guard.  Capt put them in the guard house for 2 hours.  He [?took?] a relief out & went to the church & arrested them.

[MEMORANDA]
May 27th 1862  Caldwell borrowed [?A....?]
Returned
[?M..?] Turner 16 East Capitol St.
411 5th St    499 7th St
South West corner of 6th & Pa ave
